mainContentHtml:
Quick Tricks

Fastest Tricks to Convert Active ⇄ Passive — Ace Govt Exam English

Short, exam-focused methods to convert sentences fast. Learn pattern shortcuts, see examples and solve 15+ PYQs.

Why this matters in govt exams

Active–Passive questions are common in English sections of competitive exams. Speed and accuracy come from recognizing patterns and applying a few mechanical steps. Memorize formulae below — not long grammar theory.

Universal 6-step shortcut (works in 90% of questions)

  1. Find subject (S), verb (V) and object (O). Write them as S — V — O.
  2. Swap S and O. New subject = old object.
  3. Change verb to correct passive form: be + past participle (V3). Use appropriate tense of be (is/are/was/were/has been/was being/will be).
  4. Add "by" + old subject if the agent is required (often optional in exams).
  5. Adjust pronouns & number (I → me, we → us; singular/plural agreement).
  6. Check tense & voice nuance: Progressive → "being" + V3 (was doing → was being done). Perfect → "been" + V3 (has done → has been done).

Quick tense cheatsheet (memorize these)

  • Simple Present: V(s/es) → is/are + V3 (e.g., "He writes a letter." → "A letter is written by him.")
  • Simple Past: V2 → was/were + V3
  • Present Continuous: is/are Ving → is/are being + V3
  • Past Continuous: was/were Ving → was/were being + V3
  • Present Perfect: has/have V3 → has/have been + V3
  • Modal (can/may/should): modal + V → modal + be + V3 (e.g., "They can solve" → "It can be solved.")
  • Imperative: V → Let + object + be + V3 or "Be + V3 + by ..." (use "Let" for polite commands)

Fast mental tricks (beat time pressure)

  • Spot the object first. If you can point to what receives the action, you've found the new subject for passive.
  • Look for auxiliary verbs. They tell you which form of be to use (has/have → has been/have been).
  • If "by" is missing in the options, choose the passive without agent.
  • Modal → just insert be. Example: "should finish" → "should be finished."
  • Shorten in your head: S—V—O → O—(be + V3)—(by S).

Examples (Active → Passive and back)

Active: The committee elected Raj as chairman.

Passive: Raj was elected chairman by the committee.

Active: Someone has stolen my bike.

Passive: My bike has been stolen (by someone).

Active: People speak Hindi in many parts of India.

Passive: Hindi is spoken in many parts of India.

Active: They are painting the bridge.

Passive: The bridge is being painted (by them).

Past Year Questions (PYQs) — Practice 15 sentences

Convert each to passive voice (many are adapted from common govt-exam patterns):

  1. India will launch the mission next month.
  2. They have completed the form.
  3. Shakespeare wrote Hamlet.
  4. Someone has stolen her handbag.
  5. The police arrested the thief yesterday.
  6. People speak English all over the world.
  7. The teacher will ask a question.
  8. They are building a new hospital in the town.
  9. We must finish the project by Friday.
  10. My friend made a beautiful cake for the party.
  11. He had solved the problem before the exam.
  12. The manager can approve the proposal.
  13. Someone is delivering the parcel now.
  14. Do they serve breakfast here?
  15. The government will implement the policy soon.

(Answers below — check yourself after attempting.)

Answer key — Passive forms

  1. The mission will be launched by India next month.
  2. The form has been completed (by them).
  3. Hamlet was written by Shakespeare.
  4. Her handbag has been stolen (by someone).
  5. The thief was arrested by the police yesterday.
  6. English is spoken all over the world.
  7. A question will be asked by the teacher.
  8. A new hospital is being built in the town (by them).
  9. The project must be finished by Friday.
  10. A beautiful cake was made by my friend for the party.
  11. The problem had been solved by him before the exam.
  12. The proposal can be approved by the manager.
  13. The parcel is being delivered now (by someone).
  14. Is breakfast served here?
  15. The policy will be implemented by the government soon.

Final tips for exam day

  • Practice 10–15 conversions daily — speed matters more than long explanations.
  • When options are given, eliminate those with wrong auxiliaries (e.g., "have been" vs "was being").
  • Watch out for non-finite verbs: "to do" or "doing" — they need special handling ("to be done", "being done").
  • Prefer shorter passive answers without "by" unless agent is asked or meaningful.

Prepared for quick revision — keep this page handy on your phone while practising. Good luck — ace that English paper!
